componentDescription: Evaluates whether applicant thinks about freedom, community, alternative ways of living

criteria.description: Asks about HOW TO LIVE (freedom, community, interdependence) vs. surface logistics (pay, hours). Shows genuine philosophical curiosity.

scoreGuide.3-4: Some philosophical questions but mostly surface-level.
scoreGuide.5-6: Asks genuine questions about philosophy and living. Shows depth.
scoreGuide.7-8: Deep questions about systems thinking, freedom, community. Real curiosity.
scoreGuide.9-10: Sophisticated inquiry that integrates personal + collective dimensions.

criteria.description: Can articulate what they're looking for in life and what actually matters to them. Demonstrates clear values and reasoning.

scoreGuide.1-2: Vague and directionless. 'Whatever works' without clear values.
scoreGuide.3-4: Some self-awareness but mostly surface wants (lifestyle, convenience).
scoreGuide.5-6: Clear about personal values and what they're searching for.
scoreGuide.7-8: Deeply articulate about tensions, constraints, and what they prioritize.
scoreGuide.9-10: Integrates personal needs with bigger questions about how to live.

criteria.description: Understands that personal freedom and community are linked. Sees how individual choices affect systems and vice versa.

scoreGuide.1-2: Purely individual/transactional. Doesn't connect to systems.
scoreGuide.3-4: Mentions community but doesn't show deep linkage.
scoreGuide.7-8: Sophisticated understanding of interdependence and systems.
scoreGuide.9-10: Systems-level thinking about how living structures, work, and freedom interact.

criteria.description: Shows history of building, questioning, and trying new things rather than waiting to be told what to do.

scoreGuide.1-2: Passive. No evidence of self-directed initiatives or learning.
scoreGuide.3-4: Some limited experimentation. 'I tried this once.'
scoreGuide.5-6: Clear evidence of actively building or questioning.
scoreGuide.7-8: Multiple self-directed initiatives. Learns from failures.
scoreGuide.9-10: Strong experimental mindset. Self-directed. Iterates on ideas.

criteria.description: Communicates genuinely without performing. Admits uncertainty and gaps without pretending to have all answers.

scoreGuide.1-3: Performative. Rehearsed corporate-speak. Hiding behind abstraction.
scoreGuide.4-5: Mostly genuine with occasional performance or deflection.
scoreGuide.6-7: Genuine and direct. Admits gaps and uncertainties.
scoreGuide.8-9: Deeply authentic. Vulnerable about what they don't know.
scoreGuide.10: Radically honest. No performance, no pretense.

criteria.description: Asks about the organizer's thinking and philosophy, not just logistics. Shows interest in mutual exploration.

scoreGuide.1-2: Entirely one-directional. No questions about the organizer.
scoreGuide.3-4: Only logistical questions. No philosophical curiosity.
scoreGuide.5-6: At least one genuine question about thinking or philosophy.
scoreGuide.7-8: Multiple thoughtful questions about the organizer's vision and thinking.
scoreGuide.9-10: Deep reciprocal exploration. Collaborative inquiry about mutual vision.

criteria.description: Comfort with household that includes young children (Charlie and Theo, 6). This is a home, not an office. Tolerance is acceptable; enjoyment is better; resentment is a dealbreaker.

scoreGuide.1-3: Discomfort, resentment, or stress signals about children being present. Frames kids as intrusion.
scoreGuide.4-5: Tolerant, neutral, can coexist peacefully. Acceptable baseline.
scoreGuide.6-7: Positive, comfortable, open to engagement. Good fit.
scoreGuide.8-10: Lights up about it. Has experience. Seeks connection with kids. Great fit.
